messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:58): answered 126, left 125 alone (would have had the same arguments as b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:03): Hixie, PDF version link of the spec is broken?
936e36f7a71852e10a649295a6a9729f (16:20): cool, re HTML+RDFa1.1 - would you be happier if there was /no/ mention at all of xmlns in that doc (html host lang for rdfa core)
936e36f7a71852e10a649295a6a9729f (16:20): or, mentioned only for processors for backwards compat with xhtml+rdfa1.0 with a text/html mime type
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:21): 936e36f7a71852e10a649295a6a9729f: I'd be happier if neither RDFa in HTML nor RDFa in XHTML relied on xmlns:foo
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:22): and compat with existing content was achieved by hardwiring property names
936e36f7a71852e10a649295a6a9729f (16:23): we can't do that though sadly, there are too many to hard wire
936e36f7a71852e10a649295a6a9729f (16:24): we're stuck int hat we've done everything to get rid of it, but have several million docs out there with it to handle for bc
936e36f7a71852e10a649295a6a9729f (16:24): ack, moving topic in meeting - will pick up at a later date
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:24): 936e36f7a71852e10a649295a6a9729f: don't those several million all use a handful of vocabs? Facebook, Google, Yahoo!, CC, DC?
936e36f7a71852e10a649295a6a9729f (16:26): we're moving to hard wire them (well for processors) - but doesn't handle all of them, will only handle some
936e36f7a71852e10a649295a6a9729f (16:26): and we have in charter the bc thing, so can't avoid

936e36f7a71852e10a649295a6a9729f (16:27): we've made it so authors can forget movign forward, and we don't mention xmlns, /but/ the extra rules needed to handle bc for text/html are goign to make it prominent in that doc
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:27): 936e36f7a71852e10a649295a6a9729f: charters are set by the people in the WG, so it's not really credible to point to charter as something that forces you
936e36f7a71852e10a649295a6a9729f (16:27): so 50+ mentions in HTML+RDFa1.1 - and 1 in rdfa core :|

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:30): Instead of mentioning "xmlns" explicitly, you could discourage people from using it by calling it "U+0078 LATIN SMALL LETTER X, U+006D LATIN SMALL LETTER M, U+006C LATIN SMALL LETTER L, U+006E LATIN SMALL LETTER N, U+0073 LATIN SMALL LETTER S"
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:39): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: not sure, that would encourage perverts
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:42): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6, hey, you around
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:42): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6, http://www.w3.org/2006/webapi/track/issues/35
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:42): it seems form submission works by dispatching a synthetic submit event
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:44): it also seems that Ian described "form submission" in the wrong way
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:44): it is triggered by the submit event, but it is not defined that way
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:46): filed http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=12230
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (16:50): looks like we came to the same conclusions he did
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:51): yeah, that's positive
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:51): I'm leaning towards only initEvent() resetting stuff
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:51): and then making the first argument of initEvent optional too

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (16:52): i think like you suggested, resetting in init*Event makes most sense--prevents the canceled flag from being set and then the cancel flag from being unset (inconsistent state), and avoids both the problems of early-reset and late-reset during dispatch
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:52): yup
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:52): and when we get fancy-objects I guess we should let initEvent take an object
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:52): instead of a series of arguments
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:53): so you can easily set all the properties
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:53): and then "deprecate" init*Event and not allow them on new event objects
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (16:53): the "set the properties manually" idea would be nice but that seems way too different from the current model where most event properties are readonly
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:53): http://robert.accettura.com/blog/2011/03/03/wanted-native-js-encryption/
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:54): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6, oh yeah, we could do that too still...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:54): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6, they'd still be readonly while dispatching
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (16:54): i think it'd need to ... yeah what you said
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (16:54): so you can't change them for trusted events, in particular
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:54): hmm, gotta run again; should be online at tenish though
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (16:54): it's tenish now, here :P
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:54): timezones
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (16:56): should also be defined that non-trusted submit events perform their default action, if it isn't (iirc only click is explicitly mentioned)
